text.p: Following are the main stories in Monday's Malaysian newspapers. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
NEW STRAITS TIMES
-- Landlords who inintentionally or deliberately rent their rpemises to illegal foreign workers will be charged with harbouring illegal immigrants, Deputy Home Minister Ong Ka Ting said.
-- Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad said the proposal by Cuepacs that the 850,000 civil servants be paid two months bonus this year would be discussed in a meeting with its representatives soon.
-- The export ban on logs imposed by the Sabah state government in 1991 will be partially lifted next month, Chief Minister Yong Teck Lee said.
-- The Adil Islamic Growth Fund, the first Islamic fund registered in the Labuan Offshore Financial Centre, was launched on Sunday.
-- Mobile telephone operator Mutiara Telecommunications Sdn Bhd has made available an international gateweay for its customers with the launch of its satellite earth station in Pahang.
THE STAR
-- Arab Malaysian Corp has propsoed to buy between 49 and 50 percent of Goh Ban Huat Bhd at 7.50 per share.
-- PB Securities Sdn Bhd has appointed a merchant bank to advise it on its plan to seek a listing on the KLSE main board targetted for the middle of next year.
-- United Oriental Assurance plans to list and achieve Tier-1 status by 1998.
-- Quarry operations are projected to grow by more than 15 percent a year in line with the rapid infrastructure development in Malaysia, said Institute of Quarries in Malaysia Chairman Sim Qang Seng.
UTUSAN MELAYU
-- As many as 12,25 cases of HIV in the country are now ethnic Malays or about 70 percent of all cases, the Health ministry said.
BUSINESS TIMES

-- A deal struck between Goh Ban Huat Bhd and Arab-Malaysian Corp will see the former bidding farewell to its original owners, who will also be taking its businesses in ceramic products and clay pipe making with them.

-- The current slowdown in the electronics industry is no cause for concern and will ge tback to normal by middle of next year, according to Malaysian-American Electronics Industries Chairman Roger Bertelson.

-- Sabah-based Suria Capital Holdings Bhd, en route to the main board of the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange, has seven projects in the pipeline and expects to have at least two finalised by its listing date on November 25.
-- Mutiara Telekom said future plans call for investment of 1.2 billion ringgit by 1998 to further develop its infrastructue and expand its services.
- Kuala Lumpur newsroom (603-230 8911)
